snippet: The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday night was traveling at a speed twice the speed limit on that stretch of track, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.
abstract: Federal investigators say Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia was traveling 106 miles per hour, resulting in at least seven deaths and 200 injured; authorities say it is unclear what caused accident and that speed of train may be only one of several factors; crash has shut down service between New York and Philadelphia and has raised debate among national lawmakers about state of nation's infrastructure.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, JAD MOUAWAD and EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
byline.contributor: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Emma G. Fitzsimmons reported from Philadelphia, and Jad Mouawad from New York. Daniel E. Slotnik and Rebecca White contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday night was traveling at a speed twice the speed limit on that stretch of track, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.

headline.main: Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed
headline.print_headline: Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve
